title.narrative: NP-SNDD National Program for Sub-National Democratic Development 2015-2017

description.narrative: Improved capacity, management, governance, and service delivery of the sub-national authorities, to ensure that they meet their democratic development mandate.

Det föreslagna stödet till decentraliseringsprocessen, genom det nationella reformprogrammet ”National Program for Sub-National Democratic Development”, NP-SNDD, och dess andra genomförandeplan (IP3 II), bedöms vara mycket relevant både ur ett svenskt strategiperspektiv liksom för behoven i Kambodja. Insatsen syftar på övergripande nivå till att förbättra de lokala förvaltningsnivåerna och stärka dess demokratiska mandat samt den service som ges till medborgarna. Den första implementeringsplanen avslutades 2014. Det nu föreslagna stödet är 3-årigt gällande för perioden 2015-2017.
Under denna andra fas kommer programmet fortsätta fokusera på distriktsnivån och prioriterar resultat inom 5 resultatområden: - Reform management - Demokratiskt ansvarsutkrävande - Human Resource management - Decentralisering av ansvar för social service - Decentralisering av finansiella resurser
Insatsen bedöms ha tillfredsställande förutsättningar för måluppfyllelse även om det finns utmaningar bland annat avseende ägarskapet för reformen inom linjeministerier och finansministeriet. Reformen leds på kambodjansk sida av en interministeriell kommitté (NCDD) där samtliga nyckelministerier är representerade. Denna kommitté tar beslut om de årliga arbetsplanerna och dess rapportering. Resultatramverket bedöms vara logiskt och möjligt att följa upp. Hållbarheten i stödet bedöms som god då programmet är knutet till de av Kambodjas regering prioriterade reformerna. Det rättsliga ramverket för decentraliseringen som redan har utvecklats, och som kommer att fortsätta att utvidgas under denna fas, bidrar till hållbarheten. Ett fortsatt starkt fokus på kapacitetsutveckling, främst på distriktsnivån, bedöms vara viktigt och är därtill en central del av resultatramverket. Den kambodjanska finansieringen av transfereringar till lokal nivå samt till löpande kostnader bedöms vara god även om denna i ökad utsträckning bör täcka kostnader inom själva reformprogrammet. Det externa tekniska stödet fortsätter att gradvis minska under perioden.
Det tidigare samarbetet med Kambodja inom decentraliseringsreformen visar att NCCD och dess sekretariat har system samt kapacitet för att hantera medel på ett korrekt sätt. Detta har bekräftats av både externa revisioner samt genom den bedömning av de interna kontrollsystemen som EU-delegationen lät göra under 2012. Erfarenheter visar emellertid att NCDD och dess sekretariat behöver arbeta mer effektivt och flexibelt för att nå resultat.
Avseende harmonisering och koordinering av finansiering, planering, genomförande och rapportering är bilden blandad. Under 2015-2017 kommer Sverige, EU och Schweiz till fullo använda sig av en programbaserad ansats och harmonisera sitt stöd med programmets etablerade system. Detta inkluderar en harmoniserad dialog med NCDD under 3-årsperioden. Andra givare har, på grund av interna regelverk, valt att finansiera decentraliseringsreformen genom projektstöd, snarare än via den gemensamma givarfonden. Även dessa bidrag koordineras dock inom ramen för de årliga arbetsplanerna. Dialogen mellan givarna och NCDD sker tillika via en samordnad process, främst via den tekniska arbetsgruppen för decentraliseringsprogrammet, som omfattar alla givare samt representanter från det civila samhället.

description.narrative: Sweden supported the reform with a total amount of 75 MSEK during the 2015-2017 programme phase. The funds were channeled through a joint basket fund, to which the Swiss Development Cooperation, SDC, provided additional funding. The support from the basket fund was complemented by funding from the EU, UNICEF, UNCDF and other development partners. The reform advanced at various levels during the programme phase. The contribution was a continuation from the contributions 51100006 and 51100061/62. In 2015, progress remained partly slow. Progress was made with several ministries deciding to transfer some service delivery functions to sub-national administrations (SNA). However no substantial functions, with the attached resources, were decentralized. Progress on the general mandate of the districts and municipalities proceeded more slowly than planned. Resources available through the District/Municipality (D/M) Fund were less than expected. A framework for decentralized personnel management was developed and a major share of the districts established local charters, specifying the roles of the councils and boards of governors. Efforts were taken to improve capacity development processes on local level, including the establishment of provincial resource facilities. A coordination mechanism with the other key governance reforms (public financial management and public administration) was also created during the year. Technical assistance was reduced to promote long term sustainability and to devote more resources to direct activity implementation. A communications strategy, which aimed to take a more strategic approach to promoting the decentralization reform was also developed. In 2016, a mid-term review of the 10-year National programme was carried out. Despite the slow advances in the functional reassignment and fiscal decentralization, key components of a full decentralization, the review and the annual report highlighted positive progress on the second Implementing Phase 3 (IP3). The new communications approach was implemented. Social accountability was assessed as being positive with good relationship between government and civil society at the local level. Information was shared and citizens participated in monitoring exercises. Limited functional transfers took place, with education and solid waste management being piloted. Investments on sub-national capacity development was made, representing at least half of the reform budget. The NCDD capacity assessment and the MTR indicated progress in the use of administrative and governance systems, and basic awareness about reforms. Tasks for reassignment from eight line ministries to SNA were identified in end 2016 to be delegated in 2017. However, further coordination on strategic development was needed Service delivery was still limited due to the limited fiscal transfer and functional reassignment. Taking the above into account, the deviations from plans were assessed as being moderate. In 2017, the programme was significantly delayed. A few main achievements were noted. In relation to social accountability, communes, primary schools and health centers contributed with over 90% of the Information for Citizen data, allowing citizens to get a better understanding of services to be provided. About 550 Joint Accountability Action Plans were formulated, a basis for citizens’ complaints in relation to services provided by line ministries and sub-national administration. In the area of human resource management, sub-decrees, guidelines and manuals for decentralized sub-national administration personnel management were concluded for signature. A strategy to promote women in SNA management positions was approved. Capacity building of 42,000 participants was carried out, including on gender in leadership. Most of the set targets were however not reached. Due to the dissolution of the main opposition party, CNRP, seats of CNRP elected commune counsellors were redistributed to CPP and aligned parties in September-October 2017, putting a stop to the principle of democratic accountability of elected commune counsellors. As a consequence thereof development partners decided to end or withhold funding to the decentralization reform. This had an immediate effect on the overall implementation of the programme, where the implementation rate radically decreased.
